It allows us to delve into the minds of Calgary voters in a depth no province-wide poll can, and assess the main parties' strengths and weaknesses in Calgary's different quadrants."}]},{"type":"html","tag":"p","attribs":null,"content":[{"type":"text","content":"New Democrats are comfortably ahead by double-digit margins in both northeast Calgary and the northwest, while they have a slight edge in southwest Calgary and trail the UCP in the southeast."}]},{"type":"html","tag":"p","attribs":null,"content":[{"type":"text","content":"City-wide, the NDP has support of 47 per cent of decided and leaning voters to UCP's 42 per cent. Notley is ahead, but it's a fragile lead, Janet Brown says. "}]},{"type":"html","tag":"p","attribs":null,"content":[{"type":"text","content":"\"If I were the NDP, I wouldn't be comfortable with this advantage,\" the veteran pollster said."}]},{"type":"html","tag":"p","attribs":null,"content":[{"type":"text","content":"The survey was conducted between March 23 and April 6, ahead of the May 29 provincial election."}]},{"type":"html","tag":"h2","attribs":null,"content":[{"type":"html","tag":"strong","attribs":null,"content":[{"type":"text","content":"Hello, Calgary"}]}]},{"type":"html","tag":"p","attribs":null,"content":[{"type":"text","content":"Calgary is the grand electoral prize of Alberta politics not only because it has 26 of Alberta's 87 seats, but also because its urban voters have become most likely to change their minds from election to election."}]},{"type":"html","tag":"p","attribs":null,"content":[{"type":"text","content":"In 2015, the NDP won 15 of the city's seats, and became government. In 2019, the Jason Kenney-led UCP won 23 of Calgary's ridings and their own province-wide majority."}]},{"type":"html","tag":"p","attribs":null,"content":[{"type":"text","content":"In that election, 55 per cent of Calgary voters chose United Conservatives and 32 per cent went NDP. Election results that mirror these new poll findings would constitute a massive swing in Notley's favour."}]},{"type":"html","tag":"p","attribs":null,"content":[{"type":"polopoly_embed","content":{"responsive":"true","introtext":"","id":"datawrapper-chart-7upM3","type":"datawrapper","title":"Election Voting Intention April 2023","embedcode":"\u003Ciframe title=\"Election Voting Intention April 2023\" aria-label=\"Grouped Column Chart\" id=\"datawrapper-chart-7upM3\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fdatawrapper.dwcdn.net\u002F7upM3\u002F1\u002F\" scrolling=\"no\" frameborder=\"0\" style=\"width: 0; min-width: 100% !important; border: none;\" height=\"570\" data-external=\"1\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fiframe\u003E\u003Cscript type=\"text\u002Fjavascript\"\u003E!function(){\"use strict\";window.addEventListener(\"message\",(function(a){if(void 0!==a.data[\"datawrapper-height\"]){var e=document.querySelectorAll(\"iframe\");for(var t in a.data[\"datawrapper-height\"])for(var r=0;r\u003Ce.length;r++)if(e[r].contentWindow===a.source){var i=a.data[\"datawrapper-height\"][t]+\"px\";e[r].style.height=i}}}))}(); \u003C\u002Fscript\u003E","aria-label":"Grouped Column Chart","url":"https:\u002F\u002Fdatawrapper.dwcdn.net\u002F7upM3\u002F1\u002F"}}]},{"type":"html","tag":"p","attribs":null,"content":[{"type":"text","content":"However, with a five-point advantage for the NDP, the opposition party's lead barely sits outside the margin of error."}]},{"type":"html","tag":"p","attribs":null,"content":[{"type":"text","content":"\"That lead could evaporate very quickly if the UCP has a more effective get-out-the-vote strategy than the NDP has,\" Brown said."}]},{"type":"html","tag":"p","attribs":null,"content":[{"type":"text","content":"Low approval ratings continue to dog Premier Danielle Smith, who replaced Kenney as UCP leader in October. Asked how impressed they were with Smith on a 0-10 scale, half of respondents gave her a low score of three or less, while 29 per cent said they were highly impressed with her and scored her at seven or higher. Another 20 per cent gave her a neutral rating."}]},{"type":"html","tag":"p","attribs":null,"content":[{"type":"text","content":"That is nearly the mirror opposite of Calgarians' impressions of Notley, who's front and centre in NDP campaign ads and pamphlets. Thirty per cent said they were unimpressed, 45 per cent highly impressed and 24 per cent in the middle."}]},{"type":"html","tag":"p","attribs":null,"content":[{"type":"polopoly_embed","content":{"responsive":"true","introtext":"","id":"datawrapper-chart-i3INH","type":"datawrapper","title":"Impressions of Leaders","embedcode":"\u003Ciframe title=\"Impressions of Leaders\" aria-label=\"Stacked Bars\" id=\"datawrapper-chart-i3INH\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fdatawrapper.dwcdn.net\u002Fi3INH\u002F1\u002F\" scrolling=\"no\" frameborder=\"0\" style=\"width: 0; min-width: 100% !important; border: none;\" height=\"567\" data-external=\"1\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fiframe\u003E\u003Cscript type=\"text\u002Fjavascript\"\u003E!function(){\"use strict\";window.addEventListener(\"message\",(function(a){if(void 0!==a.data[\"datawrapper-height\"]){var e=document.querySelectorAll(\"iframe\");for(var t in a.data[\"datawrapper-height\"])for(var r=0;r\u003Ce.length;r++)if(e[r].contentWindow===a.source){var i=a.data[\"datawrapper-height\"][t]+\"px\";e[r].style.height=i}}}))}(); \u003C\u002Fscript\u003E","aria-label":"Stacked Bars","url":"https:\u002F\u002Fdatawrapper.dwcdn.net\u002Fi3INH\u002F1\u002F"}}]},{"type":"html","tag":"h2","attribs":null,"content":[{"type":"html","tag":"strong","attribs":null,"content":[{"type":"text","content":"Notley of the north"}]}]},{"type":"html","tag":"p","attribs":null,"content":[{"type":"text","content":"The next premier will have to effectively strategize how to stack up wins in Calgary's various quadrants."}]},{"type":"html","tag":"p","attribs":null,"content":[{"type":"text","content":"UCP support is strongest in Calgary's southeast, where the party leads the NDP 52 per cent to 40."}]},{"type":"html","tag":"p","attribs":null,"content":[{"type":"text","content":"The NDP is performing best in the northeast, leading 48 to 33. It's ahead 52 to 38 in the northwest, while its 45-to-43 edge in southwest Calgary puts the parties in a virtual tie."}]},{"type":"html","tag":"p","attribs":null,"content":[{"type":"text","content":"These numbers would translate into 18 Calgary seats won by Notley's party and eight for Smith's, according to Brown's estimates."}]},{"type":"html","tag":"p","attribs":null,"content":[{"type":"text","content":"\"That means the NDP looks like they're in position to win the majority of seats in Calgary, but I'm not sure that 18 seats is enough to win province-wide.\""}]},{"type":"html","tag":"p","attribs":null,"content":[{"type":"text","content":"Even if you combine 18 Calgary seats and a sweep of the 20 ridings in Edmonton — Notley's hometown stronghold — that still wouldn't be enough to give the NDP a 44-seat majority and victory. The opposition party would also have to make gains in Alberta's smaller communities or rural ridings, where the United Conservatives are strongest."}]},{"type":"html","tag":"p","attribs":null,"content":[{"type":"polopoly_embed","content":{"responsive":"true","introtext":"","id":"datawrapper-chart-5JXf6","type":"datawrapper","title":"Seat Projections","embedcode":"\u003Ciframe title=\"Seat Projections\" aria-label=\"Map\" id=\"datawrapper-chart-5JXf6\" src=\"https:\u002F\u002Fdatawrapper.dwcdn.net\u002F5JXf6\u002F1\u002F\" scrolling=\"no\" frameborder=\"0\" style=\"width: 0; min-width: 100% !important; border: none;\" height=\"773\" data-external=\"1\"\u003E\u003C\u002Fiframe\u003E\u003Cscript type=\"text\u002Fjavascript\"\u003E!function(){\"use strict\";window.addEventListener(\"message\",(function(a){if(void 0!==a.data[\"datawrapper-height\"]){var e=document.querySelectorAll(\"iframe\");for(var t in a.data[\"datawrapper-height\"])for(var r=0;r\u003Ce.length;r++)if(e[r].contentWindow===a.source){var i=a.data[\"datawrapper-height\"][t]+\"px\";e[r].style.height=i}}}))}(); \u003C\u002Fscript\u003E","aria-label":"Map","url":"https:\u002F\u002Fdatawrapper.dwcdn.net\u002F5JXf6\u002F1\u002F"}}]},{"type":"html","tag":"p","attribs":null,"content":[{"type":"text","content":"Other smaller parties continue to barely register. The Alberta Party is hanging on to three per cent while one per cent each said they would support the Wildrose Independence Party, Alberta Liberals and Alberta Greens."}]},{"type":"html","tag":"p","attribs":null,"content":[{"type":"text","content":"Six per cent of respondents are considered \"orphaned voters,\" those polled who don't like any of the options."}]},{"type":"html","tag":"p","attribs":null,"content":[{"type":"text","content":"\"Those voters have already rejected the two major parties. So I don't think there's much chance that those parties can convert those voters into supporters at this point,\" Brown said."}]},{"type":"html","tag":"h2","attribs":null,"content":[{"type":"html","tag":"strong","attribs":null,"content":[{"type":"text","content":"Who's blue, who's orange"}]}]},{"type":"html","tag":"p","attribs":null,"content":[{"type":"text","content":"The NDP are particularly strong among Calgary women, leading the UCP by 51 per cent to 41, while the parties are virtually even with men. NDP retains its traditional strength among young voters, but is also leading the UCP by 10 percentage points among senior citizens, the poll suggests."}]},{"type":"html","tag":"p","attribs":null,"content":[{"type":"text","content":"The UCP enjoys a healthy lead with Calgarians with no post-secondary education or some, while respondents with university degrees clearly prefer the New Democrats. "}]},{"type":"html","tag":"p","attribs":null,"content":[]},{"type":"html","tag":"p","attribs":null,"content":[{"type":"text","content":"While some city quadrants appear to clearly prefer one party over the other — and the NDP is better in the inner city, the UCP in the suburbs — there would be more subtle distinctions if you drilled down further, said Jack Lucas, an associate professor of political science at the University of Calgary."}]},{"type":"html","tag":"p","attribs":null,"content":[{"type":"text","content":"\"When you zoom in on the city of Calgary itself, there are districts within the city that are particularly ideologically diverse and competitive,\" he said. \"When you zoom in within those districts, you even see particular neighbourhoods or communities that are especially competitive."}]},{"type":"html","tag":"p","attribs":null,"content":[{"type":"text","content":"\"So it's a battleground, no matter what scale you're thinking about.\""}]},{"type":"html","tag":"hr","attribs":null,"content":[]},{"type":"html","tag":"p","attribs":null,"content":[{"type":"html","tag":"em","attribs":null,"content":[{"type":"text","content":"CBC News' random survey of 1,000 of Calgarians was conducted using a hybrid method between March 23 - April 6, by Edmonton-based Trend Research under the direction of"}]},{"type":"html","tag":"a","attribs":{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.planetjanet.ca\u002Fprojects-cbc"},"content":[{"type":"html","tag":"em","attribs":null,"content":[{"type":"html","tag":"u","attribs":null,"content":[{"type":"text","content":" Janet Brown Opinion Research."}]}]}]},{"type":"html","tag":"em","attribs":null,"content":[{"type":"text","content":" The sample is representative of regional, age and gender factors. The margin of error is +\u002F- 3.1 percentage points, 19 times out of 20. For subsets, the margin of error is larger."}]}]},{"type":"html","tag":"p","attribs":null,"content":[{"type":"html","tag":"em","attribs":null,"content":[{"type":"text","content":"The survey used a hybrid methodology that involved contacting survey respondents by telephone and giving them the option of completing the survey at that time, at another more convenient time, or receiving an email link and completing the survey online. Trend Research contacted people using a random list of numbers, consisting of half landlines and half cellphone numbers. id="detailContent"><span class="detail-link-label sclt-storySectionLink"><a class="" href="/news/canada/calgary"><span>Calgary</span></a></span><h1 class="detailHeadline" lang="en">Alberta NDP could make huge gains in Calgary and win popular vote, new poll suggests — but still lose election</h1><div class="detailSummary">Danielle Smith's UCP could lose most seats in Calgary but still win election, according to a special Calgary-only poll commissioned by CBC News.</div><div class="share"><div class="viafoura"><h2 class="a11y">Social Sharing</h2><div class="vf-widget vf-share-bar-horizontal" data-widget="sharebar" data-button-view="false" data-url="https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/calgary/janet-brown-poll-calgary-ndp-ucp-rachel-notley-danielle-smith-quadrants-1.6806245" data-show-labels="true" data-show-counters="false" data-show-total="false"></div></div></div><h2 class="deck" lang="en">Opposition could win popular vote and most Calgary seats, but still lose election</h2><div class="byline"><figure class="imageMedia author-image full" data-testid="image-figure"><div class="placeholder"><img loading="lazy" alt="" src="https://i.cbc.ca/1.5253954.1664396049!/fileImage/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/square_140/joel.jpg" data-testid="image-img"/></div></figure><div class="bylineDetails"><span class="authorText"><a class="" href="/news/canada/calgary/author/joel-dryden-1.5253918">Joel Dryden</a>, <a class="" href="/news/canada/calgary/author/jason-markusoff-1.6448323">Jason Markusoff</a></span> <span class="bullet"> · </span>CBC News<!-- --> <span class="bullet"> · </span><time class="timeStamp" dateTime="2023-04-11T12:22:46.751Z" data-testid="time">Posted: Apr 11, 2023 8:00 AM EDT | Last Updated: 3 hours ago</time></div></div><div class="storyWrapper"><figure class="imageMedia leadmedia-story full" data-testid="image-figure"><div class="placeholder"><img alt="Two women are pictured in a collage." src="https://i.cbc.ca/1.6806309.1681166303!/fileImage/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/16x9_780/poll.jpg" data-testid="image-img"/></div><figcaption class="image-caption">Alberta NDP Leader Rachel Notley and Alberta Premier Danielle Smith, pictured in file photos. A new poll commissioned by CBC News suggests Calgary remains hotly contested and will have significant implications on final seat counts in the upcoming election.<!-- --> <!-- -->(Jeff McIntosh/The Canadian Press)</figcaption></figure><div class="commentCount"><button class="commentCount-link"><div class="commentCount-text-container"><div class="viafoura"><vf-conversations-count></vf-conversations-count></div><div class="commentCount-text"><span> comments</span></div></div></button><span class="commentCount-icon"><svg viewBox="0 0 32 32" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true"><path d="M20.95,17H11a1,1,0,0,0,0,2h10a1,1,0,0,0,0-2Zm2-6H9a1,1,0,0,0,0,2h14a1,1,0,0,0,0-2ZM16,0C7.14,0,0,6.26,0,14a12.55,12.55,0,0,0,6,10.9v7.07l7-4.25a18.71,18.71,0,0,0,3,.25c8.82,0,16-6.25,16-14S24.78,0,16,0Zm0,25.95a16.29,16.29,0,0,1-3.37-.37l-4.7,2.82.06-4.63A11.56,11.56,0,0,1,2,14C2,7.36,8.24,2,16,2s14,5.36,14,12-6.26,12-14,12Zm0,0"></path></svg></span></div><div class="story"><p><em><strong>EDITOR'S NOTE: CBC News commissioned this public opinion research in late March, roughly two months before Albertans vote in the next election on May 29.</strong></em></p><p><em><strong>As with all polls, this one is a snapshot in time. </strong></em></p><p><em><strong>This analysis is one in a series of articles to come out of this research. </strong></em></p><hr/><p>The Alberta NDP is ahead of the United Conservative Party in Calgary, the battleground city where Rachel Notley's party will likely need a landslide to overtake Danielle Smith's government, according to a new 1,000-person poll of Calgarians.</p><p>Given that both <a href="https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/calgary/alberta-politics-election-ndp-calgary-1.6761221">parties</a> and almost all <a href="https://www.cbc.ca/listen/cbc-podcasts/407-west-of-centre/episode/15975514-live-special-what-do-voters-want-out-of-albertas-election">observers</a> have declared that how blue or orange Alberta's largest city is will determine the election's winner, CBC News commissioned this special poll only of Calgarians by Janet Brown Opinion Research. It allows us to delve into the minds of Calgary voters in a depth no province-wide poll can, and assess the main parties' strengths and weaknesses in Calgary's different quadrants.</p><p>New Democrats are comfortably ahead by double-digit margins in both northeast Calgary and the northwest, while they have a slight edge in southwest Calgary and trail the UCP in the southeast.</p><p>City-wide, the NDP has support of 47 per cent of decided and leaning voters to UCP's 42 per cent. Notley is ahead, but it's a fragile lead, Janet Brown says. </p><p>"If I were the NDP, I wouldn't be comfortable with this advantage," the veteran pollster said.</p><p>The survey was conducted between March 23 and April 6, ahead of the May 29 provincial election.</p><h2><strong>Hello, Calgary</strong></h2><p>Calgary is the grand electoral prize of Alberta politics not only because it has 26 of Alberta's 87 seats, but also because its urban voters have become most likely to change their minds from election to election.</p><p>In 2015, the NDP won 15 of the city's seats, and became government. In 2019, the Jason Kenney-led UCP won 23 of Calgary's ridings and their own province-wide majority.</p><p>In that election, 55 per cent of Calgary voters chose United Conservatives and 32 per cent went NDP. Election results that mirror these new poll findings would constitute a massive swing in Notley's favour.</p><div><div class="dataWrapperEmbed"><iframe loading="lazy" id="datawrapper-chart-7upM3" scrolling="no" frameBorder="0" title="Election Voting Intention April 2023" src="https://datawrapper.dwcdn.net/7upM3/1/" style="height:400px;width:100%;border:none" aria-label="Grouped Column Chart: Election Voting Intention April 2023"></iframe></div></div><p>However, with a five-point advantage for the NDP, the opposition party's lead barely sits outside the margin of error.</p><p>"That lead could evaporate very quickly if the UCP has a more effective get-out-the-vote strategy than the NDP has," Brown said.</p><p>Low approval ratings continue to dog Premier Danielle Smith, who replaced Kenney as UCP leader in October. Asked how impressed they were with Smith on a 0-10 scale, half of respondents gave her a low score of three or less, while 29 per cent said they were highly impressed with her and scored her at seven or higher. Another 20 per cent gave her a neutral rating.</p><p>That is nearly the mirror opposite of Calgarians' impressions of Notley, who's front and centre in NDP campaign ads and pamphlets. Thirty per cent said they were unimpressed, 45 per cent highly impressed and 24 per cent in the middle.</p><div><div class="dataWrapperEmbed"><iframe loading="lazy" id="datawrapper-chart-i3INH" scrolling="no" frameBorder="0" title="Impressions of Leaders" src="https://datawrapper.dwcdn.net/i3INH/1/" style="height:400px;width:100%;border:none" aria-label="Stacked Bars: Impressions of Leaders"></iframe></div></div><h2><strong>Notley of the north</strong></h2><p>The next premier will have to effectively strategize how to stack up wins in Calgary's various quadrants.</p><p>UCP support is strongest in Calgary's southeast, where the party leads the NDP 52 per cent to 40.</p><p>The NDP is performing best in the northeast, leading 48 to 33. It's ahead 52 to 38 in the northwest, while its 45-to-43 edge in southwest Calgary puts the parties in a virtual tie.</p><p>These numbers would translate into 18 Calgary seats won by Notley's party and eight for Smith's, according to Brown's estimates.</p><p>"That means the NDP looks like they're in position to win the majority of seats in Calgary, but I'm not sure that 18 seats is enough to win province-wide."</p><p>Even if you combine 18 Calgary seats and a sweep of the 20 ridings in Edmonton — Notley's hometown stronghold — that still wouldn't be enough to give the NDP a 44-seat majority and victory. The opposition party would also have to make gains in Alberta's smaller communities or rural ridings, where the United Conservatives are strongest.</p><div><div class="dataWrapperEmbed"><iframe loading="lazy" id="datawrapper-chart-5JXf6" scrolling="no" frameBorder="0" title="Seat Projections" src="https://datawrapper.dwcdn.net/5JXf6/1/" style="height:400px;width:100%;border:none" aria-label="Map: Seat Projections"></iframe></div></div><p>Other smaller parties continue to barely register. The Alberta Party is hanging on to three per cent while one per cent each said they would support the Wildrose Independence Party, Alberta Liberals and Alberta Greens.</p><p>Six per cent of respondents are considered "orphaned voters," those polled who don't like any of the options.</p><p>"Those voters have already rejected the two major parties. So I don't think there's much chance that those parties can convert those voters into supporters at this point," Brown said.</p><h2><strong>Who's blue, who's orange</strong></h2><p>The NDP are particularly strong among Calgary women, leading the UCP by 51 per cent to 41, while the parties are virtually even with men. NDP retains its traditional strength among young voters, but is also leading the UCP by 10 percentage points among senior citizens, the poll suggests.</p><p>The UCP enjoys a healthy lead with Calgarians with no post-secondary education or some, while respondents with university degrees clearly prefer the New Democrats. </p><p></p><p>While some city quadrants appear to clearly prefer one party over the other — and the NDP is better in the inner city, the UCP in the suburbs — there would be more subtle distinctions if you drilled down further, said Jack Lucas, an associate professor of political science at the University of Calgary.</p><p>"When you zoom in on the city of Calgary itself, there are districts within the city that are particularly ideologically diverse and competitive," he said. "When you zoom in within those districts, you even see particular neighbourhoods or communities that are especially competitive.</p><p>"So it's a battleground, no matter what scale you're thinking about."</p><hr/><p><em>CBC News' random survey of 1,000 of Calgarians was conducted using a hybrid method between March 23 - April 6, by Edmonton-based Trend Research under the direction of</em><a href="https://www.planetjanet.ca/projects-cbc"><em><u> Janet Brown Opinion Research.</u></em></a><em> The sample is representative of regional, age and gender factors. The margin of error is +/- 3.1 percentage points, 19 times out of 20. For subsets, the margin of error is larger.</em></p><p><em>The survey used a hybrid methodology that involved contacting survey respondents by telephone and giving them the option of completing the survey at that time, at another more convenient time, or receiving an email link and completing the survey online. Trend Research contacted people using a random list of numbers, consisting of half landlines and half cellphone numbers. Telephone numbers were dialled up to five times at five different times of day before another telephone number was added to the sample. </em></p></div></div><div class="authorprofile"><h2 class="title-reUIw" data-testid="title-tag">ABOUT THE AUTHOR</h2><div class="authorprofile-container"><div class="authorprofile-image-container"><figure class="imageMedia author-image full" data-testid="image-figure"><div class="placeholder"><img loading="lazy" alt="" srcSet="https://i.cbc.ca/1.5253954.1664396049!/fileImage/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/square_300/joel.jpg 300w,https://i.cbc.ca/1.5253954.1664396049!/fileImage/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/square_460/joel.jpg 460w,https://i.cbc.ca/1.5253954.1664396049!/fileImage/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/square_620/joel.jpg 620w" sizes="(max-width: 258pxpx) 258pxpx" src="https://i.cbc.ca/1.5253954.1664396049!/fileImage/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/square_620/joel.jpg" data-testid="image-img"/></div></figure></div><div class="authorprofile-name-container"><a class="" href="/news/canada/calgary/author/joel-dryden-1.5253918">Joel Dryden</a><p class="authorprofile-title"></p></div></div><p class="authorprofile-biography">Joel is a reporter/editor with CBC Calgary. In fall 2021, he spent time with CBC's bureau in Lethbridge. He was previously the editor of the Airdrie City View and Rocky View Weekly newspapers. He hails from Swift Current, Sask. author.name: Joel Dryden
author.description:
Joel is a reporter/editor with CBC Calgary. In fall 2021, he spent time with CBC's bureau in Lethbridge. He was previously the editor of the Airdrie City View and Rocky View Weekly newspapers. He hails from Swift Current, Sask. 

Reach him by email at joel.dryden@cbc.ca

author.name: Jason Markusoff
author.description: Jason Markusoff analyzes what's happening — and what isn't happening, but probably should be — in Calgary and sometimes farther afield. He's written in Alberta for nearly two decades with Maclean's magazine, the Calgary Herald and Edmonton Journal. He appears regularly on Power and Politics' Power Panel and various other CBC current affairs shows. Reach him at jason.markusoff@cbc.ca

main.description: Danielle Smith's UCP could lose most seats in Calgary but still win election, according to a special Calgary-only poll commissioned by CBC News.
main.alternateName: Opposition could win popular vote and most Calgary seats, but still lose election
main.name: Alberta NDP could make huge gains in Calgary and win popular vote, new poll suggests — but still lose election
main.headline: Alberta NDP could make huge gains in Calgary and win popular vote, new poll suggests — but still lose election

imageObjects.name: Poll
imageObjects.description: Alberta NDP Leader Rachel Notley and Alberta Premier Danielle Smith, pictured in file photos. A new poll commissioned by CBC News suggests Calgary remains hotly contested and will have significant implications on final seat counts in the upcoming election.

description: Danielle Smith's UCP could lose most seats in Calgary but still win election, according to a special Calgary-only poll commissioned by CBC News.
text: The Alberta NDP is ahead of the United Conservative Party in Calgary, the battleground city where Rachel Notley's party will likely need a landslide to overtake Danielle Smith's government, according to a new 1,000-person poll of Calgarians.Given that both  and almost all  have declared that how blue or orange Alberta's largest city is will determine the election's winner, CBC News commissioned this special poll only of Calgarians by Janet Brown Opinion Research. It allows us to delve into the minds of Calgary voters in a depth no province-wide poll can, and assess the main parties' strengths and weaknesses in Calgary's different quadrants.New Democrats are comfortably ahead by double-digit margins in both northeast Calgary and the northwest, while they have a slight edge in southwest Calgary and trail the UCP in the southeast.City-wide, the NDP has support of 47 per cent of decided and leaning voters to UCP's 42 per cent. Notley is ahead, but it's a fragile lead, Janet Brown says. "If I were the NDP, I wouldn't be comfortable with this advantage," the veteran pollster said.The survey was conducted between March 23 and April 6, ahead of the May 29 provincial election.Calgary is the grand electoral prize of Alberta politics not only because it has 26 of Alberta's 87 seats, but also because its urban voters have become most likely to change their minds from election to election.In 2015, the NDP won 15 of the city's seats, and became government. In 2019, the Jason Kenney-led UCP won 23 of Calgary's ridings and their own province-wide majority.In that election, 55 per cent of Calgary voters chose United Conservatives and 32 per cent went NDP. Election results that mirror these new poll findings would constitute a massive swing in Notley's favour.However, with a five-point advantage for the NDP, the opposition party's lead barely sits outside the margin of error."That lead could evaporate very quickly if the UCP has a more effective get-out-the-vote strategy than the NDP has," Brown said.Low approval ratings continue to dog Premier Danielle Smith, who replaced Kenney as UCP leader in October. Asked how impressed they were with Smith on a 0-10 scale, half of respondents gave her a low score of three or less, while 29 per cent said they were highly impressed with her and scored her at seven or higher. Another 20 per cent gave her a neutral rating.That is nearly the mirror opposite of Calgarians' impressions of Notley, who's front and centre in NDP campaign ads and pamphlets. Thirty per cent said they were unimpressed, 45 per cent highly impressed and 24 per cent in the middle.The next premier will have to effectively strategize how to stack up wins in Calgary's various quadrants.UCP support is strongest in Calgary's southeast, where the party leads the NDP 52 per cent to 40.The NDP is performing best in the northeast, leading 48 to 33. It's ahead 52 to 38 in the northwest, while its 45-to-43 edge in southwest Calgary puts the parties in a virtual tie.These numbers would translate into 18 Calgary seats won by Notley's party and eight for Smith's, according to Brown's estimates."That means the NDP looks like they're in position to win the majority of seats in Calgary, but I'm not sure that 18 seats is enough to win province-wide."Even if you combine 18 Calgary seats and a sweep of the 20 ridings in Edmonton — Notley's hometown stronghold — that still wouldn't be enough to give the NDP a 44-seat majority and victory. The opposition party would also have to make gains in Alberta's smaller communities or rural ridings, where the United Conservatives are strongest.Other smaller parties continue to barely register. The Alberta Party is hanging on to three per cent while one per cent each said they would support the Wildrose Independence Party, Alberta Liberals and Alberta Greens.Six per cent of respondents are considered "orphaned voters," those polled who don't like any of the options."Those voters have already rejected the two major parties. So I don't think there's much chance that those parties can convert those voters into supporters at this point," Brown said.The NDP are particularly strong among Calgary women, leading the UCP by 51 per cent to 41, while the parties are virtually even with men. NDP retains its traditional strength among young voters, but is also leading the UCP by 10 percentage points among senior citizens, the poll suggests.The UCP enjoys a healthy lead with Calgarians with no post-secondary education or some, while respondents with university degrees clearly prefer the New Democrats. While some city quadrants appear to clearly prefer one party over the other — and the NDP is better in the inner city, the UCP in the suburbs — there would be more subtle distinctions if you drilled down further, said Jack Lucas, an associate professor of political science at the University of Calgary."When you zoom in on the city of Calgary itself, there are districts within the city that are particularly ideologically diverse and competitive," he said. "When you zoom in within those districts, you even see particular neighbourhoods or communities that are especially competitive."So it's a battleground, no matter what scale you're thinking about."
title: Alberta NDP could make huge gains in Calgary and win popular vote, new poll suggests — but still lose election
